cards.title: F1 / Hamilton clinches second straight win at Silverstone
cards.rawTitle: Hamilton clinches second straight win at Silverstone

item.title: Lewis Hamilton wins the 2015 British F1 GP at Silverstone
item.trailText: Lewis Hamilton wins British F1 Grand Prix
item.standFirst: Lewis Hamilton wins British F1 Grand Prix

displayImages.caption: Young Formula One fans look forward to seeing their heroes in action. Photograph: Charles Coates/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Young Formula One fans look forward to seeing their heroes in action
displayImages.cleanCaption: Young Formula One fans look forward to seeing their heroes in action.

displayImages.caption: Lewis Hamilton climbs a fence to wave to the fans. Photograph: Charles Coates/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Lewis Hamilton climbs a fence to wave to the fans
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lewis Hamilton climbs a fence to wave to the fans.

displayImages.caption: The drivers stand for the national anthem. Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The drivers stand for the national anthem
displayImages.cleanCaption: The drivers stand for the national anthem.

displayImages.caption: Felipe Massa takes the lead from Hamilton at the start. Photograph: Frank Augstein/AP
displayImages.altText: Felipe Massa takes the lead from Hamilton at the start
displayImages.cleanCaption: Felipe Massa takes the lead from Hamilton at the start.

displayImages.caption: Jenson Button retires after just two laps. Another nightmare race for the Brit and McLaren Honda. Photograph: Dan Istitene/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Jenson Button retires after just two laps. Another nightmare race for the Brit and McLaren Honda
displayImages.cleanCaption: Jenson Button retires after just two laps. Another nightmare race for the Brit and McLaren Honda.

displayImages.caption: Lap three, Hamilton attacks Massa, but runs wide and lets Valtteri Bottas in. Photograph: Ben Stansall/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Lap three, Hamilton attacks Massa, but runs wide and lets Bottas in
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lap three, Hamilton attacks Massa, but runs wide and lets Valtteri Bottas in.

displayImages.caption: Max Verstappen spins his Scuderia Toro Rosso, ending up in the gravel on lap five. Photograph: Sutton Images/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Max Verstappen spins his Scuderia Toro Rosso, ending up in the gravel on lap five
displayImages.cleanCaption: Max Verstappen spins his Scuderia Toro Rosso, ending up in the gravel on lap five.

displayImages.caption: Massa sets the fastest lap after six, but Hamilton soon takes that honour. Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Felipe Massa sets the fastest lap after six, but hamilton soon takes that title
displayImages.cleanCaption: Massa sets the fastest lap after six, but Hamilton soon takes that honour.

displayImages.caption: There is a bit of tension over the Williams radio on lap 10, with Bottas being told not to race Massa. “But I have pace!” says Bottas. Photograph: Clive Mason/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Theres a bit of tension over the Williams radio on lap ten, with Bottas being told not to race Massa. “But I have pace!” whines Bottas
displayImages.cleanCaption: There is a bit of tension over the Williams radio on lap 10, with Bottas being told not to race Massa. “But I have pace!” says Bottas.

displayImages.caption: Hamilton pitts on lap 20, the first of the leading pack to do so. Photograph: Mark Thompson/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Hamilton pitts on lap 20, first of the leading pack
displayImages.cleanCaption: Hamilton pitts on lap 20, the first of the leading pack to do so.

displayImages.caption: The rain arrives, but that does not deter Hamilton. Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: the rain arrives in Oxford, not to deter Hamilton
displayImages.cleanCaption: The rain arrives, but that does not deter Hamilton.

displayImages.caption: Lap 39, Vettel powers past team-mate Kimi Raikkonen and into fifth place. Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Lap 39. Vettel powers past team-mate Raikkonen and into fifth place.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lap 39, Vettel powers past team-mate Kimi Raikkonen and into fifth place.

displayImages.caption: Lap 41, Nico Rosberg quickly gains on Massa. Photograph: Martin Rickett/PA
displayImages.altText: Lap 41, Nico Rosberg quickly gains on Massa
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lap 41, Nico Rosberg quickly gains on Massa.

displayImages.caption: Lap 42, Rosberg storms back – and he cuts the gap on Hamilton to just a couple of seconds!  Photograph: Reuters/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Lap 42. Rosberg has stormed back – and he’s cut the gap on Hamilton to just a couple of seconds!
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lap 42, Rosberg storms back – and he cuts the gap on Hamilton to just a couple of seconds!

displayImages.caption: Manor Marussia’s British driver Will Stevens goes wide, and destroys the nose of his car on lap 49, so close to finishing his first British Grand Prix. Photograph: Martin Rickett/PA
displayImages.altText: Manor Marussia’s British driver Will Stevens goes wide, and destroys the nose of his car on lap 49, so close to finishing his first British Grand Prix
displayImages.cleanCaption: Manor Marussia’s British driver Will Stevens goes wide, and destroys the nose of his car on lap 49, so close to finishing his first British Grand Prix.

displayImages.caption: Hamilton wins the British Grand Prix! It’s a third victory at Silverstone for the defending champion. Photograph: Reuters/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Lewis Hamilton wins the British Grand Prix! It’s a third victory at Silverstone for the defending champion
displayImages.cleanCaption: Hamilton wins the British Grand Prix! It’s a third victory at Silverstone for the defending champion.

displayImages.caption: “I’m so happy with that!” says Hamilton over the team radio – and who can blame him? He’s the first British driver to win his home grand prix from pole since Damon Hill in 1994. Photograph: Dunbar/LAT/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: “I’m so happy with that!” says Hamilton over the team radio – and who can blame him? He’s the first British driver to win his home grand prix from pole since Damon Hill in 1994
displayImages.cleanCaption: “I’m so happy with that!” says Hamilton over the team radio – and who can blame him? He’s the first British driver to win his home grand prix from pole since Damon Hill in 1994.

displayImages.caption: Hamilton sprays champagne on teammate Nico Rosberg. Photograph: Andrej Isakovic/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Hamilton sprays champagne on teammate Nico Rosberg
displayImages.cleanCaption: Hamilton sprays champagne on teammate Nico Rosberg.

displayImages.caption: Hamilton kisses the trophy, joining Jack Brabham, Niki Lauda and Michael Schumacher in winning three British Grands Prix. Photograph: Reuters/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Hamilton kisses the trophy, joining Jack Brabham, Niki Lauda and Michael Schumacher in winning three British Grands Prix.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Hamilton kisses the trophy, joining Jack Brabham, Niki Lauda and Michael Schumacher in winning three British Grands Prix.

displayImages.caption: Hamilton lifts the trophy as he celebrates with the fans. Photograph: Martin Rickett/PA
displayImages.altText: Hamilton lifts the trophy as he celebrates with the fans.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Hamilton lifts the trophy as he celebrates with the fans.

displayImages.caption: The Silverstone fans get to cheers on their hero. Photograph: Peter J Fox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The Silverstone fans get to cheers on their hero.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Silverstone fans get to cheers on their hero.

image.altText: Young Formula One fans look forward to seeing their heroes in action
image.cleanCaption: Young Formula One fans look forward to seeing their heroes in action.

cards.title: Cycling / Tour de France 2015: stages one and two
cards.rawTitle: Tour de France 2015: stages one and two

item.title: Tour de France 2015: stages one and two
item.trailText: We round up the best images from stages one and two of this year’s Tour de France. Featuring the opening individual time trial stage over 13.8Km in Utrecht, and stage two , a 166km stage between Utrecht and Zelande.
item.standFirst: We round up the best images from stages one and two of this year’s Tour de France. Featuring the opening individual time trial stage over 13.8km in Utrecht, and stage two, a 166km stage between Utrecht and Zelande.

displayImages.caption:
Stage 1
The Dutch fans line the streets to watch the opening stage. Photograph: Yoan Valat/EPA
displayImages.altText:
Stage 1
Tour de France 2015 1st stage
epa04830770 Spectators watch riders on big screen during the 1st stage of the 102nd edition of the Tour de France 2015 cycling race, an individual time trial over 13.8Km in Utrecht, Netherlands, 04 July 2015. EPA/YOAN VALAT
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Stage 1
The Dutch fans line the streets to watch the opening stage.

displayImages.caption: The 2014 champion Vincenzo Nibali sets off. Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/Reuters
displayImages.altText: 2014 Champion Vincenzo Nibali sets off
displayImages.cleanCaption: The 2014 champion Vincenzo Nibali sets off.

displayImages.caption: Tom Dumoulin kept the crowd alive along the route. Photograph: Jeff Pachoud/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Tom Dumoulin kept the crowd alive along the route, the dutchman was close, but lifted off at the scond half of the course to finish in fourth place
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tom Dumoulin kept the crowd alive along the route.

displayImages.caption: Team Sky’s Chris Froome finishes 50 seconds down. Photograph: Sebastien Nogier/EPA
displayImages.altText: Team Sky rider Chris Froome finishes 50 seconds down
displayImages.cleanCaption: Team Sky’s Chris Froome finishes 50 seconds down.

displayImages.caption: Fabian Cancellara strains as he finishes third, six seconds off the pace. Photograph: Peter Dejong/AP
displayImages.altText: Fabian Cancellara strains as he finishes third,six seconds off the pace
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fabian Cancellara strains as he finishes third, six seconds off the pace.

displayImages.caption: Rohan Dennis set the pace early and had to wait till the end to confirm his victory. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Dennis Rohan set the pace early and had to wait till the end to confirm his victory
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rohan Dennis set the pace early and had to wait till the end to confirm his victory.

displayImages.caption: Etixx-Quick Step’s Tony Martin pushes off at the start and manages second place, five seconds behind Dennis. Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Etixx-Quick Step’s Tony Martin pushes off at the start and manages second place, five seconds behind Dennis
displayImages.cleanCaption: Etixx-Quick Step’s Tony Martin pushes off at the start and manages second place, five seconds behind Dennis.

displayImages.caption: Sky’s Richie Porte, not renowned for his time trial speed, finished one minute and six seconds down. Photograph: Yoan Valat/EPA
displayImages.altText: Sky’s Richie Porte, not renowned for his time trial speed, finished one minute six seconds down
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sky’s Richie Porte, not renowned for his time trial speed, finished one minute and six seconds down.

displayImages.caption: Dennis of BMC sets record speed to finish with a time of 14 minutes, 56 seconds. Photograph: Bas Czerwinski/EPA
displayImages.altText: Rohan Dennis of BMC sets record speed to finish with a time of 14 minutes, 56 seconds
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dennis of BMC sets record speed to finish with a time of 14 minutes, 56 seconds.

displayImages.caption: Dennis claims the first maillot jaune of the 2015 Tour de France. Photograph: Doug Pensinger/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Rohan Dennis sets record speed to claim first maillot jaune
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dennis claims the first maillot jaune of the 2015 Tour de France.

displayImages.caption:
Stage 2
Everyone gets in the mood for the start of the race as the polka dot jersey practises flyboarding. Photograph: Stefano Rellandini/Reuters
displayImages.altText:
Stage 2
Everyone gets in the mood for the start of the race as the polka dot jersey practises flyboarding
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Stage 2
Everyone gets in the mood for the start of the race as the polka dot jersey practises flyboarding.

displayImages.caption: A sticker reading ‘36 Weeks = 252 Days = 6,048 Hours Away From Home’ is attached to a bicycle of the Team Lotto NL Jumbo. Photograph: Sebastien Nogier/EPA
displayImages.altText: A sticker reading ‘36 Weeks = 252 Days = 6,048 Hours Away From Home’ is attached to a bicycle of the Team Lotto NL Jumbo
displayImages.cleanCaption: A sticker reading ‘36 Weeks = 252 Days = 6,048 Hours Away From Home’ is attached to a bicycle of the Team Lotto NL Jumbo.

displayImages.caption: Stage one winner, Dennis, awaits the start of the second stage. Photograph: Sebastien Nogier/EPA
displayImages.altText: Stage one winner, BMC’s Rohan Dennis, awaits the start of the second stage.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Stage one winner, Dennis, awaits the start of the second stage.

displayImages.caption: The peloton passes through the city centre of Utrecht during the ceremonial procession prior to the start. Photograph: Christophe Ena/AP
displayImages.altText: The pack passes through the city center of Utrecht during the ceremonial procession prior to the start
displayImages.cleanCaption: The peloton passes through the city centre of Utrecht during the ceremonial procession prior to the start.

displayImages.caption: The stage gets underway. Photograph: Jeroen Jumelet/EPA
displayImages.altText: The pack get underway
displayImages.cleanCaption: The stage gets underway.

displayImages.caption: Riding in the Netherlands wouldn’t be the same without a windmill. Here the peloton passes one in Montfoort. Photograph: Laurent Cipriani/AP
displayImages.altText: Riding in the Netherlands wouldn’t be the same without a windmill. Here the peloton passes one in Montfoort.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Riding in the Netherlands wouldn’t be the same without a windmill. Here the peloton passes one in Montfoort.

displayImages.caption: The peloton crosses a bridge. Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The peloton crosses a bridge.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The peloton crosses a bridge.

displayImages.caption: The peloton on the Erasmusbrug (Erasmus bridge)  Photograph: Robin Utrecht/EPA
displayImages.altText: The peloton on the Erasmusbrug (Erasmus bridge)
displayImages.cleanCaption: The peloton on the Erasmusbrug (Erasmus bridge)

displayImages.caption: Every gap along the route was lined with passionate Dutch fans all the way from Utrecht to Zelande. Photograph: Miroslav Dakov/Demotix/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Every gap onlong the route was lined with passionate dutch fans all the way from Utrecht to Zelande
displayImages.cleanCaption: Every gap along the route was lined with passionate Dutch fans all the way from Utrecht to Zelande.

displayImages.caption: The peloton passes alongside the wind turbines which line the coast. Photograph: Sebastien Nogier/EPA
displayImages.altText: The peloton in action alongside the wind turbines which line the coast
displayImages.cleanCaption: The peloton passes alongside the wind turbines which line the coast.

displayImages.caption: The peloton rides along the North Sea coast. Photograph: Bryn Lennon/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The peloton rides along the North Sea coast
displayImages.cleanCaption: The peloton rides along the North Sea coast.

displayImages.caption: Movistar’s Adrian Malori talks to an Astana rider as they lead the peloton through a storm. Photograph: Sebastien Nogier/EPA
displayImages.altText: Movistar’s Adrian Malori talks to an Astana rider as they lead the peleton through a rain storm
displayImages.cleanCaption: Movistar’s Adrian Malori talks to an Astana rider as they lead the peloton through a storm.

displayImages.caption: André Greipel celebrates as he crosses the finish line ahead of Mark Cavendish. Photograph: Eric Feferberg/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: André Greipel celebrates as he crosses the finish line ahead of Mark Cavendish.
displayImages.cleanCaption: André Greipel celebrates as he crosses the finish line ahead of Mark Cavendish.

displayImages.caption: Fabian Cancellara celebrates as he is awarded the yellow jersey. Photograph: Doug Pensinger/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Fabian Cancellara celebrates as he is awarded the yellow jersey
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fabian Cancellara celebrates as he is awarded the yellow jersey.

cards.title: Cycling / Stage Two highlights from the Tour de France
cards.rawTitle: Stage Two highlights from the Tour de France

item.title: Stage Two highlights from the Tour de France
item.trailText: Day two from the the Tour de France
item.standFirst: Day two from the The Tour de France saw the riders cycle from Utrecht to Zeeland. The first week can be tricky and this was proven here, as the rain and wind played their part. With Etixx-Quickstep and Tinkoff Saxo setting a fast pace it was a bad day for Vincenzo Nibali, Nairo Quintana, and Thibault Pinot who lost over a minute to fellow general classification rivals Alberto Contador and Chris Froome

cards.title: Football / Fiji hammer Micronesia 38-0 at Pacific Games
cards.rawTitle: Fiji hammer Micronesia 38-0 at Pacific Games

item.title: Fiji hammer Micronesia 38-0 at Pacific Games - video highlights
item.trailText: Organisers of the Pacific Games believe Fiji has broken the record for the biggest win in international football after defeating Micronesia 38-0
item.standFirst: Organisers of the Pacific Games believe Fiji has broken the record for the biggest win in international football after defeating Micronesia 38-0 on Sunday. Fiji were already up 21-0 by half-time with Antonio Tuivuna scoring ten goals. Organisers of the tournament say the previous record was held by Australia when they beat American Samoa 31-0 in a qualifier for the 2002 World Cup

cards.title: Football / Chile fans celebrate country's Copa América victory over Argentina
cards.rawTitle: Chile fans celebrate country's Copa América victory over Argentina

item.title: Chile fans celebrate Copa América victory
item.trailText: Thousands of Chilean football fans join their national team in celebrating after winning their first Copa América title on Saturday
item.standFirst: Thousands of Chilean football fans join their national team in celebrating after winning their first Copa América title on Saturday. Greeted by roaring supporters, the Chilean team hold a parade before meeting with President Michelle Bachelet. Chile defeated Argentina 4-1 on penalties after a 0-0 draw. Chile's last appearance in a Copa América final was in 1987 where they lost to Uruguay

cards.title: In pictures / Tom Jenkins's best images from days five and six at Wimbledon
cards.rawTitle: Tom Jenkins's best images from days five and six at Wimbledon

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: days five and six
item.trailText: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is down in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic last couple of days
item.standFirst: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is down in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic last couple of days

displayImages.caption: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute’s silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.
displayImages.altText: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute's silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Spectators on Murray Mount stand for the minute’s silence to remember the victims of the Tunisia beach attack.

displayImages.caption: Bethanie Mattek-Sands puts ice on her neck during a break in her match with Belinda Bencic. Mattek-Sands, who frequently dyes her hair in a range of colours, said the tournament had ‘gotten a little excessive’ in its obsession with white, having tightened its rules last year to ban anything more than a 1cm coloured trim – even ruling out coloured underwear worn under white garments.
displayImages.altText: Bethanie Mattek-Sands puts ice on her neck during a break in her match with Belinda Bencic. Mattek-Sands, who frequently dyes her hair in a range of colours, said the tournament had “gotten a little excessive” in its obsession with white, having tightened its rules last year to ban anything more than a 1cm coloured trim – even ruling out coloured underwear worn under white garments.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bethanie Mattek-Sands puts ice on her neck during a break in her match with Belinda Bencic. Mattek-Sands, who frequently dyes her hair in a range of colours, said the tournament had ‘gotten a little excessive’ in its obsession with white, having tightened its rules last year to ban anything more than a 1cm coloured trim – even ruling out coloured underwear worn under white garments.

displayImages.caption: A spectator hands Nick Kyrgios his racket after he flung it so forcefully into the grass that it bounced several metres into the terraces, narrowly missing someone. ‘I’m not the biggest believer in saying nothing out there or being a robot,’ Kyrgios said. ‘I feel you should express yourself. You know – it’s a sport.’
displayImages.altText: A spectator hands Nick Kyrgios his racket after he flung his racket so forcefully into the grass that it bounced several metres into the terraces, narrowly missing someone. “I’m not the biggest believer in saying nothing out there or being a robot,” Kyrgios said, “I feel you should express yourself. You know – it’s a sport.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: A spectator hands Nick Kyrgios his racket after he flung it so forcefully into the grass that it bounced several metres into the terraces, narrowly missing someone. ‘I’m not the biggest believer in saying nothing out there or being a robot,’ Kyrgios said. ‘I feel you should express yourself. You know – it’s a sport.’

displayImages.caption: Kyrgios went on to defeat No7 seed Milos Raonic and said afterwards, ‘I’m focusing but at the same time I’m having fun. When I find that balance, I play some really good tennis. I thought I was doing that today in the second, third and fourth.’
displayImages.altText: Nick Kyrgios went on to defeat No7 seed Milos Raonic and said afterwards, “I’m focusing but at the same time I’m having fun. When I find that balance, I play some really good tennis. I thought I was doing that today in the second, third and fourth.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kyrgios went on to defeat No7 seed Milos Raonic and said afterwards, ‘I’m focusing but at the same time I’m having fun. When I find that balance, I play some really good tennis. I thought I was doing that today in the second, third and fourth.’

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic slides to return the ball to Bernard Tomic as the world No1 recorded a 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 victory that was utterly ruthless. Tomic was generous in his praise. “I can’t even describe it in words,” he said. “Too good, too good.”
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic slides to return the ball to Bernard Tomic as the world No1 recorded a 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 victory that was utterly ruthless. Tomic was generous in his praise. “I can’t even describe it in words,” he said. “Too good, too good.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic slides to return the ball to Bernard Tomic as the world No1 recorded a 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 victory that was utterly ruthless. Tomic was generous in his praise. “I can’t even describe it in words,” he said. “Too good, too good.”

displayImages.caption: Heather Watson cannot reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.
displayImages.altText: Heather Watson can't reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-time Wimbledon champion to the very brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Heather Watson cannot reach a Serena Williams serve during her defeat on Centre Court. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by Serena in a dramatic final set.

displayImages.caption: Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Watson. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She didn’t think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.’
displayImages.altText: Serena Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Heather Watson. “What’s the toughest away match to play?” Williams was asked afterwards. “A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?” She didn’t think for long. “I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Williams is emotional as she celebrates her victory over Watson. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She didn’t think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain. For sure.’

displayImages.caption: Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Williams. ‘It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards, ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’
displayImages.altText: Heather Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Serena Williams. “It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super-, super-close,” Watson said afterwards, “I think that’s what really hurts the most.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Watson waves to the crowd after her defeat to Williams. ‘It was a tough, tough ask today, but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards, ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’

displayImages.caption: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’
displayImages.altText: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: “When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dustin Brown fails to reach a return during his defeat to Viktor Troicki. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’

displayImages.caption: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.
displayImages.altText: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A multiple exposure of Sam Groth serving in his defeat to Roger Federer. Groth’s serve of 147mph during the match was the second fastest ever recorded at Wimbledon.

displayImages.caption: James Ward returns during his five-set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.
displayImages.altText: James Ward returns during his five set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.
displayImages.cleanCaption: James Ward returns during his five-set defeat to Vasek Pospisil. An heroic failure almost matching Heather Watson’s. Both British players though left the stage with a lot more credit in the bank than they arrived with.

displayImages.caption: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four-set win.
displayImages.altText: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four set win.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The last British singles player still standing was again Andy Murray. Here, he returns the ball to Andreas Seppi on Centre Court during his four-set win.

displayImages.caption: Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. ‘Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,’ Murray said courtside. ‘When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.’
displayImages.altText: Andy Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Andreas Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. “Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,” Murray said courtside. “When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Murray had to come through a lot of drama to beat Seppi on the sixth evening of the 2015 championships. Both players required medical attention for injuries. ‘Towards the end of the second set my right shoulder started to tighten up,’ Murray said courtside. ‘When he took that injury break it cooled down a bit. I thought I played very well. There was that part of the second set where I struggled but the way I finished the match is the way I want to play the rest of the tournament, with a lot of energy.’
